replies.bodyText:
It's not about whether the target exists or not; it's true while the rabbit is moving towards the target and set to false once one of several possible conditions hold to stop the task.

there is no target
the rabbit has reached the target
there is no longer any path to the target

@@ -28,6 +28,11 @@ CLASS net/minecraft/class_3532 net/minecraft/util/math/MathHelper
 	METHOD method_15347 approximatelyEquals (FF)Z
 		ARG 0 a
 		ARG 1 b

+		COMMENT Returns the closest valeu to {@code end} which is within {@code maxChange} of {@code start}

timeline.bodyText: clamp in range? cap delta? don't like this name much
timeline.author: liach
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -28,6 +28,11 @@ CLASS net/minecraft/class_3532 net/minecraft/util/math/MathHelper
 	METHOD method_15347 approximatelyEquals (FF)Z
 		ARG 0 a
 		ARG 1 b
+	METHOD method_15348 capChange (FFF)F

replies.bodyText: It's not clamping, the change is added to the start, rather than being between start and end. I'm not sure how delta is any clearer than change.
replies.author: Earthcomputer
liach

replies.bodyText:
You correctly point out that there are two ways of looking at what this method does.

You could look at it like a clamp, where end clamped between start - abs(maxChange) and start + abs(maxChange). This is how the method is actually implemented.
You could look at it as changing a variable from start to end, but only being able to change it by up to a certain amount (maxChange).

Although these are mathematically equivalent, I believe the second one is much more intuitive to think about, and also fits better with how the method is actually used.
replies.author: Earthcomputer

replies.bodyText: Sure, good to know that.
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: I think stepChange(current, target, step) or stepTowards(current, target, step) would be more intuitive. The purpose is to update a value in steps every tick until it reaches a target value.
replies.author: Runemoro

timeline.bodyText: What's the difference between this and capChange? How is an unwrapped angle treated differently than any other float?
timeline.author: Runemoro
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -106,6 +111,11 @@ CLASS net/minecraft/class_3532 net/minecraft/util/math/MathHelper
 		ARG 0 value
 	METHOD method_15386 ceil (F)I
 	METHOD method_15387 floorMod (II)I
+	METHOD method_15388 capUnwrappedAngularChange (FFF)F

replies.bodyText: It's like capChange except it calls subtractAngles to subtract the angle. Using capChange on angles instead of this method (or capAngularChange) may produce uncapped or otherwise incorrect results in some cases.
replies.author: Earthcomputer
